reviewText: (Please read all my review & not stop at the end of the first two sentances if you disagree with my support of Israel) At first I was a bit shy buying this movie, I believe in the cause of Israel & its divine right to exist. I am extreemly careful about anything that would bring the Jewish people and the nation of Israel into disrepute or partake of anything that even resembles anti Semitism - there was something about this movie that intrigued me, I am so glad it did. This movie will move you, its ending is something that the viewer would never expect and without spoiling it for anyone, make sure that anyone prone to expressions of tearful emotions has a generous supply of tissues handy. In saying that, it is a movie that either gender can watch and very much enjoy; the acting is well above par with no well 'Known' actors involved and those in it do an excellent job. Shot on location in the Middle East they story highlights the misery that both sides of the conflict endure - though I am unashamedly pro-Israeli, I do not deny the suffering that the Arab peoples of this land suffer and this movie fairly and accuratly converys the suffering that both sides experience. This is not so much a 'them' and 'us' conflict story parse that we often see on the TV news most nights, even though that is what is indicated on the DVD cover, it is at a completly different level. It is a movie that the Directors and Producers have managed to avoid the common rhetoric of this most painful conflict and remind us that it is the individuals that count, not the politics, and how the most brutal of wars or conflicts cannot keep the most tender of hearts apart, even when they come from opposite sides of the spectrum.

reviewText: Language of the Enemy was a wonderful story that hopefully will help many to understand that barriers between different cultures can be broken down and that there is some hope in the world.  Beautiful but very sad story.  Excellent service, price etc.

reviewText: My wife and I have traveled in Israel and the West Bank, and so the cover and topic of this film caught our interest while perusing options at the local Redbox. We sat down to watch it, unsure what to expect.Shot entirely in Israel, "Language of the Enemy" is ambitious and has a lot to offer. Romi, a Jewish man living in Boston, returns to Israel after three years when his father is killed in a bus bombing incident there. Soon, he is recruited to go undercover in Ramallah, using his knowledge of Arabic to help track down his father's killers. Complications arise when he meets a beautiful, single nurse, a woman named Joleh. She is Muslim, albeit a fairly liberal one. He is Jewish, though not a very good one in his own mind. They are sworn enemies, and yet their attraction is immediate, leading to life-altering choices for both of them."Language of the Enemy" moves from political thriller to romantic comedy to social commentary. It touches on religious and ethnic issues, showing honor to all concerned, while never whitewashing either side's faults. The script walks that line with surprising agility, although the romantic aspects get over-dramatized at a few points, with sweeping music and one or two sappy lines. Overall, though, the acting is strong, the action scenes tense, and the humor warm and welcome. Despite its faults, it's a thought-provoking film, capable of providing entertainment while also tugging on hearts and expanding minds. This is a "Language . . ." that should be discovered by many.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The language of my enemy"  is a haunting and touching film. supported by an  agile script, captures with notable intensity and profound realism, the in and outs of an endless conflict in which non of both sides is disposed to give a chance to a peaceful dialogue. Nevertheless and leaving aside the enormous barrier of cultures and beliefs, an North American entrepreneur from Boston goes to Israel to be present in the funeral of his father, victim of a criminal slaughter . Once he arrives he accepts to bring some information from the side of the enemy thanks to his knowledge about the language. But the destiny has for him an unexpected surprise that will change both lives.There's a remarkable highlight: the superb performance of F. Murray Abraham as Wahid, that it might well deserve him another nomination as Best supporting Actor.On the other hand the versatile direction his director Jim Abrahms is a true legendary triumph.This is a wise choice that carves in relief the whereabouts of a war that seems to have no end, with a sensitive touch of Romeo and Juliet, just at the end of the dramatic resolution.Watch it and you will be aware that love transcends all sort of beliefs.
summary: Two different religions, but hate is the same!

reviewText: I had low expectations for this movie - the description and cover blurb made me think it would be another in the genre of "bad Arabs, wonderful Israelis" propaganda but I was very pleasantly surprised at the way from the very start, it approached all its characters and all sides in this conflict with great compassion and insight and reflecting a depth of knowledge. The characters are all very engaging and the story is both enlightening and entertaining with unexpected twists. The locations are authentic and really draw you in. I'd strongly recommend this movie!
summary: An unexpected gem of a movie!

reviewText: This is one of those "lost" movies that everyone has to see. I am not going to get into the plot because that would give away the story ending which is a real towelsoaker. Even an alien from another planet would be effected by what transpiresin the movie. I will explain one aspect of the movie! the meaning behind the words "The Language of the Enemy" is not what I would thought they were. The meaning is on another level entirely. And thats another point, there are so many levels to this movie, I would be hard pressed to start writing about all of them.
